Award.AwardTitle: Manipulating photochemical reactivity through restricted bond rotations
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism-B program is supporting the fundamental research of Professor Jayaraman Sivaguru at North Dakota State University, Fargo, ND. Professor Sivaguru is developing a general strategy for transferring axial chirality to point chirality during chemical reactions initiated by UV and/or visible light. By using atropisomeric chiral chromophores that feature restricted bond rotations, the photochemistry and photophysics will be investigated in detail. The outcome from the proposed studies will provide avenues to control excited state chemistry which complement existing thermal methodologies. These studies will enable the development of a coherent approach to gain fundamental understanding of molecular interactions in light initiated reactions. Professor Sivaguru will integrate the research and educational components through the PICNICS (Parents Involvement with Children, Nurturing Intellectual Curiosity in Science) program. The PICNICS program is an outreach program for high school students in the Fargo-Moorhead area that exposes them to research and is expected to have a long-term impact on the career path they take in their undergraduate studies. The research and outreach activities provide an excellent training avenue for graduate students to enhance their intellectual scientific partnership during their doctoral studies. The outcome of the research program will have a significant impact on the basic concepts related to photoscience and asymmetric photochemistry and will broadly influence other fields such as synthetic chemistry, nanoscience and materials science.

The proposed research is aimed at building a comprehensive knowledge and understanding of excited state processes by evaluating chiral energy transfer in systems featuring atropisomeric chromophores during light initiated reactions. Through molecular restriction built within these chromophores, it is anticipated that new aspects of excited state reactivity will be observed. The investigation will explore systems featuring restricted bond rotations to understand new dynamic aspects and how they can be harnessed to control excited state reactivity initiated by UV and/or visible light and compare their photo-reactivity with the corresponding achiral non-atropisomeric systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our investigation on “Manipulating photochemical reactivity through restricted bond rotations” led to a comprehensive understanding on how to control excited state processes leading to new reactive pathways. In addition, molecular restrictions paved a way to develop asymmetric light initiated reactions. The investigations led to the discovery of a) Photoene-reaction; b) Transposed Paternò-Büchi and Aza Paternò-Büchi reactions. In addition, the project led to the development of hydrazides as photo-auxiliaries for carrying out visible light transformations. The investigations also led to the development of energy transfer catalysis for excited state transformations. A seminal outcome of the program was the development of new and unknown excited state reactivities both under UV and visible light irradiations. These research findings were disseminated in top-tier peer-reviewed chemistry journals. In addition, authoritative reviews were written on the topic to highlight the importance of the developed strategy. Some of the published articles appeared as cover-art or Frontispiece showcasing the importance of the developed strategies from the program. The findings from the projects were also disseminated in various national and international conferences and were well received by the scientific community as evidenced by the awards and recognition given to students who carried out the proposed research and the PI who directed the research program.

 

Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the completed research projects, students gained expertise in the fields’ of organic photochemistry, photophysics, photocatalysis and asymmetric photochemistry. The research program led to intellectual, scientific and educational initiatives that integrated research with academic goals of teaching, training and learning. The research program complemented the curriculum at both BGSU and NDSU by providing a cutting edge research atmosphere in both traditional and modern areas of chemistry and in particular photochemistry. The intellectual training of students helped them gain experimental and intellectual competence that was reflected in their career path after successful completion of their PhD.  The program successfully recruited and supervised students from underrepresented groups (African-American student; US citizen and Four female students) all of who completed their doctoral investigation and received their degree during the award period. Students who successfully completed their doctoral work took up positions as post-doctoral fellows in top institutions in the US (Columbia Univ., Harvard Univ., UPenn, USC, Boston Univ.). In addition, one of the students (minority African-American Student / US citizen) took up a research position at the US ARMY Research Labs, Aberdeen, MD. USA. Thus, the project enabled the training of next generation scientists.

 

The program also trained undergraduate students that included students from underrepresented groups. The research program also trained high school students. The funding for the research program enabled the PI to develop and sustain a unique outreach program for high school students in the Fargo-Moorhead area called PICNICS “Parents Involvement with Children, Nurturing Intellectual Curiosity in Sciences”. Eighteen high school students participated in the program during the award period. A total of sixty five students have participated in the PICNICS summer program since its inception in 2007. This program continues to train and provide research opportunities to high school students. This has enabled talented high school students to gain a wide range of experience and expertise in interdisciplinary and collaborative research and create an infrastructure for the integration of research and education. This initiative would not have been feasible without the generous funding from NSF.
